周五， OpenAI 的最高管理层出人意料地进行了改组，宣布首席执行官 Sam Altman 已被解雇，并将离开公司和董事会，立即生效。首席技术官 Mira Murati 被任命为临时首席执行官。

据报道，奥特曼的罢免是在内部“审议程序”之后进行的，该程序发现他“与董事会的沟通不够坦诚，阻碍了董事会履行职责的能力”，该公司宣布。因此，“董事会不再对他继续领导 OpenAI 的能力充满信心。”

拥有流行人工智能聊天机器人ChatGPT的OpenAI感谢Altman“为OpenAI的创立和发展做出的许多贡献”，但相信“作为公司研究、产品和安全职能的领导者，Mira非常有资格介入临时首席执行官的角色。”董事会补充说，“对她在这一过渡时期领导 OpenAI 的能力充满信心。”

OpenAI 董事会由公司首席科学家 Ilya Sutskever 以及董事长兼总裁 Greg Brockman 组成。不持有公司股权的独立顾问也是董事会成员：Quora 首席执行官 Adam D'Angelo、科技企业家 Tasha McCauley 以及乔治城安全和新兴技术中心的隐私倡导者 Helen Toner。尽管奥特曼在离职前担任公司首席执行官，但也被认为是董事会的独立顾问。

我很喜欢在 openai 的时光。这对我个人来说是变革性的，希望对世界也有一点变革。最重要的是，我喜欢与这些才华横溢的人一起工作。

稍后将有更多关于接下来的事情要说。

🫡

— Sam Altman (@sama) 2023 年 11 月 17 日

在过去的一年里，Altman 的个人形象随着生成式 AI 技术的迅速崛起而不断增长，这使他成为 OpenAI 和整个新兴行业的非正式代表。 Alman 曾担任 Y Combinator 总裁，曾出席国会专门委员会和委员会，出席参议院 AI Insight 论坛，并多次参加行业会议。

考虑到奥特曼在被解雇之前的几天里一直在大力宣传他的公司及其产品，周五宣布的突然消息无疑令人惊讶。

就在上周，Altman 在 OpenAI 的 2023 DevDay 上宣布了更快、响应更灵敏的GPT-4 Turbo平台以及更小的、特定于应用程序的模型，简称为GPT 。周四奥特曼出席了在旧金山举行的亚太经济合作组织首席执行官峰会。 “有些东西已经发生了质的变化，”他在活动期间说道。“现在我可以和这个东西交谈了。它就像我一直承诺的‘星际迷航’计算机一样......我认为今年世界上很多地方都经历了一次困境赶上。”

奥特曼和穆拉蒂并不是唯一陷入这场洗牌的人。布罗克曼也将辞去董事会主席一职，但仍留在 OpenAI，向新任首席执行官汇报。

Altman 于 2015 年联合创立了 OpenAI，并自 2019 年起担任其首席执行官。该公司去年 11 月发布的超受欢迎的 ChatGPT 对话式 AI 被认为掀起了生成式 AI 热潮。该系统最初构建在 GPT-3.5 平台之上，最初使用户能够使用自然语言与数字代理（比上一代 Siri、Alexa 和 Assistant 更强大）进行对话。这些功能迅速扩展到包括多种语言和模式，以及输出计算机代码和通过 API 访问控制远程进程和设备的能力。

这是一个发展的故事。请查看更新。

由于该平台上的反犹太主义内容日益强烈，另一家主要广告商正在从 X 上撤下其广告。 Axios 报道称，在亲纳粹帖子附近发现其广告且 X 所有者埃隆·马斯克似乎公开支持反犹太主义阴谋论后，苹果选择“暂停”该平台上的所有广告。

一天前，IBM 暂停了X 上的广告活动，原因是监管机构 Media Matters 发布了一份报告， 发现该公司的广告出现在 X 上的亲纳粹内容旁边。它说还出现在亲纳粹表情包和帖子附近。

X 的一位高管此前告诉 Engadget，Media Matters 识别的帖子不再可货币化，并且“X 系统不会故意将品牌主动放置在此类内容旁边，品牌也不会主动尝试通过放置来支持此类内容” ”。 X首席执行官琳达·亚卡里诺(Linda Yaccarino)也表示，“X也非常清楚我们为打击反犹太主义和歧视所做的努力。”

苹果没有立即回应置评请求，但这并不是该公司第一次对该平台在马斯克领导下的发展方向及其作为主要广告商的角色表示担忧。苹果首席执行官蒂姆·库克 (Tim Cook) 9 月份表示，该公司“不断”质疑是否应该继续在 X 上投放广告。 去年，由于两位首席执行官之间的“误会”，苹果还曾短暂暂停在 X（当时的 Twitter）上投放广告。马斯克和库克后来在库比蒂诺的苹果总部会面，显然解决了分歧。

(Photo by Jaap Arriens/NurPhoto via Getty Images)Elon Musk Changes Twitter Bird Logo To X What is RCS and how is it different from SMS and iMessage?

戏剧性的逆转是，苹果本周宣布将从2024 年开始提供 RCS 支持。这一决定有效地结束了 iOS 和 Android 之间最旷日持久、最令人困惑的冲突之一。如果您不确定这意味着什么，请不要担心：我们将列出苹果采用 GSMA 下一代消息协议后可能发生的变化。

什么是短信？

短消息服务 (SMS) 是地球上最普遍的消息传递协议之一。它可以追溯到移动技术的早期。 1992 年 12 月，时任沃达丰工程师的尼尔·帕普沃斯 (Neil Papworth)发送了第一条 SMS 短信，祝老板“圣诞快乐”。到 2011 年初，全球大约 80% 的手机用户（估计有 35 亿人）每月都会发送短信。

然而，到 2023 年，该标准存在一些明显的缺陷。 SMS 消息的长度不得超过 160 个字符，并且您发送的文本不能包含照片、视频、音频或 GIF。为此，手机长期以来一直采用一种称为多媒体消息服务 (MMS) 的支持协议，但它也有其技术限制，包括令人遗憾的消息大小限制。 SMS 也不支持端到端加密。

尽管短信在即时通讯平台主导的时代显得有些过时，但它有一个明显的优势：短信是通过运营商的移动网络传送的，这意味着使用该技术不需要数据计划。这一事实意味着 SMS 经常充当更高级协议（包括 iMessage）的后备。

什么是RCS？

RCS 是“丰富通信服务”的缩写，尽管有时它也被称为“高级消息传递”。不管怎样，它通常被定位为短信和彩信的下一代替代品。 RCS 允许用户利用以前 WhatsApp 等 OTT 消息平台独有的许多功能。

例如，RCS 通用配置文件包括对已读回执和打字指示器的全面支持。它还可以促进适当的群聊，并允许用户发送高分辨率图像、视频和音频剪辑。截至今年早些时候，Google 的 RCS 实施还默认为一对一和群聊提供端到端加密 (E2EE)。

与 SMS 文本不同，RCS 消息通过移动数据连接或 Wi-Fi 链路进行路由，并以 SMS 作为后备。因此，旧协议可能不会很快消失。

关于 RCS，需要记住的一件重要事情是，它不是、也从未被设想为即时消息应用程序的替代品或竞争对手。从本质上讲，RCS 是移动电话运营商之间以及电话与运营商之间的通信协议。利用 RCS 不需要注册新服务。只要您的手机和运营商支持 RCS，并且您使用兼容的应用程序（例如Google Messages） ，您就可以利用该协议提供的所有功能 - 当然，前提是您要发送消息的对象是这些相同的要求。

iMessage 如何融入这一切？

苹果公司于 2011 年 6 月推出了 iMessage，就在同年晚些时候史蒂夫·乔布斯去世前几个月。与 RCS 不同，iMessage 是一种由 Apple 独家控制的专有消息协议，仅在 iPhone、iPad、Apple Watch 和 Mac 设备上可用（ 除非有一些非官方的解决方法）。从 2024 年开始，Apple 计划在其消息应用程序中集成对 RCS 的支持。然而，目前这两个协议无法相互通信。因此，当用户尝试向使用 Android 手机的人发送文本和媒体文件时，Apple 的消息应用程序将默认使用短信/彩信。

从 iMessage 用户的角度来看，Android 用户可能会感觉自己陷入了过去的消息时代——尽管后者并不是造成这种情况的过错。由于 iMessage 依赖 SMS/MMS 进行 Android 通信，因此媒体文件最终会出现像素化，没有任何已读回执或打字指示器，并且忘记尝试让多个 iPhone 和 Android 用户参与单个群聊。

我们是怎么来到这里的？

尽管 RCS 的工作早在 Apple 发布 iMessage 之前就已开始，但该协议有一个主要缺点，注定其推出速度缓慢。 RCS 是一个多利益相关方项目，其中包括代表整个移动通信行业利益的贸易机构 GSMA 的参与。 2015 年，Google 收购了 Jibe Mobile，在 RCS 的扩散中发挥了更积极的作用。以 Jibe 的技术为基础，谷歌实际上提供了将 RCS 生态系统粘合在一起的粘合剂，但长期以来，该公司在让参与 RCS 的每个人实现共同目标方面做得很差。

事实上，RCS 的早期阶段就出现了错误的开始，一些运营商，包括由AT&T、T-Mobile 和 Verizon组成的集团，组建了一家短暂的合资企业，以推动该协议向前发展，然后最终与谷歌结盟。就连三星也曾做过一段时间的自己的事情，最终也同意将 Messages by Google 作为其在美国手机上默认的消息应用程序。

因此，Apple 没有理由采用 RCS。毕竟，它为什么要给一个笨手笨脚的竞争对手免费赠品呢？就在去年，情况似乎几乎不可能在短期内发生改变。当被问及 RCS 消息传递时，苹果首席执行官蒂姆·库克 (Tim Cook) 在 2022 年代码大会上表示：“我没有听到我们的用户要求我们为此投入大量精力。” “ 给你妈妈买一部 iPhone ”是他对此事的最后一句话。

但也是在去年，欧盟通过了具有里程碑意义的《数字市场和服务法案》 (DMA)。该立法要求“看门人”不得偏袒自己的系统或限制第三方在其中进行互操作。守门人是任何符合特定财务和使用资格的公司。根据法律规定，苹果公司就是这样一家公司。

11 月初，谷歌向欧盟委员会发出申诉，称 iMessage 违反了 DMA。 Apple 的 RCS 公告恰逢各公司向欧盟普通法院提出 DMA 挑战的最后期限，这可能并非偶然。周五，欧盟宣布苹果正在争夺其 DMA 分配。该公司投诉的细节并未公开，但彭博社上周报道称，苹果计划挑战 iMessage 和 App Store 的“看门人”称号。

苹果对 RCS 的支持是否意味着 iPhone 上绿色文本气泡的终结？

现在说还为时过早。周四，苹果公司提供了一些关于计划如何在其设备上显示和处理 RCS 消息的宝贵细节。更重要的是，该公司确实指出，iMessage“将继续成为苹果用户最好、最安全的消息体验。”也就是说，即使您认为该声明意味着 iMessage 将继续以不同于 iPhone、iPad 或 Mac 发送的文本的方式显示来自非 Apple 设备的文本，Apple 采用 RCS 将为 iOS 和 Android 带来更好的用户体验用户。

同样，苹果需要提供具体细节，但很容易想象，在 RCS 的帮助下，其消息应用程序可以正确显示从 Android 手机发送的高分辨率图像和视频，并允许 iOS 和 Android 用户参与群聊。没有任何东西破损。周四，苹果还表示将与 GSMA 成员合作改进现有的通用配置文件协议，重点是在标准中添加端到端加密。

当然，这种互操作性是否能消除绿色泡沫的耻辱还很难回答。

尽管《半条命》是 Valve 历史的重要组成部分，但迄今为止它还没有在 Steam Deck 上得到验证。相反，它带有“可玩”标签。 Valve 写道：“我们终于让我们的游戏通过了我们自己的‘验证’测试，而且……我们失败得非常严重。” “所以我们修复了这个问题！在重新测试游戏后， 《半条命》正式带有绿色复选标记。”因此，这意味着它应该可以在您的新 Steam Deck OLED上顺利运行。

最重要的是，如果您的库中还没有《半条命》，那么您可以在 11 月 20 日之前在 Steam 上免费下载《半条命》 。各种《半条命》和 Valve 捆绑包也在打折，而《半条命 Alyx》则有 66% 的折扣20.39 美元。

值得注意的是，Valve 现在认为《半条命》周年纪念版“是最终版本，也是我们今后将继续支持的版本”。因此，Valve 表示《半条命：源》在 Steam 上的地位将不那么突出，但仍将保持可用，以便模组制作者可以继续使用其资源。

Valve 表示： “我们于 1998 年 11 月 19 日推出了《半条命》。我们对当时所打造的作品感到非常自豪，并且对从那时起就一直享受这款游戏的玩家社区深怀感激。” “近年来，这款游戏并没有像我们目录中的许多其他游戏那样受到那么多关注，因此我们认为这个里程碑是一个很好的机会，可以改善玩家体验并添加一些有趣的新游戏方式。”

最后但并非最不重要的一点是，Valve 发布了一部新纪录片来纪念 25 周年。这部时长 65 分钟的影片中，开发者和 Valve 联合创始人讨论了公司的早期历史以及他们在《半条命》中工作的回忆。生日快乐，弗里曼先生。

科技行业正受到经济不景气、新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 大流行和一些明显的商业失误的影响。虽然这导致了 2022 年的裁员，但不幸的是，2023 年的裁员人数有所增加。跟踪这些举措可能很困难，因此我们将所有重大裁员汇总在一处，并将继续更新此故事随着局势的发展。

十一月

育碧蒙特利尔裁员

11 月初，育碧在蒙特利尔办事处解雇了 98 名员工，该办事处被认为是该公司最大的内部开发团队的所在地。大多数失业者从事的是工商管理和 IT 行业。总体而言，该公司在最新的季度收益报告中表示，过去12个月已裁员约1,000人，包括裁员和不替换自愿离职的员工。

巡航

据报道，通用汽车旗下无人驾驶汽车子公司 Cruise 在 11 月份告诉员工，计划解雇部分员工。就在同一周，通用汽车因行人碰撞事故召回了Cruise 的整个 950 辆机器人出租车车队。克鲁斯尚未透露谁或有多少人将失去工作。

折断

Snap 解雇了 20 名产品经理，声称此举将加快决策速度。

亚马逊

据路透社和彭博社等多家知名新闻媒体报道，亚马逊从其游戏部门裁员 180 人。此次裁员包括亚马逊支持的 Twitch 频道 Crown 的全体员工。另外，11 月晚些时候，亚马逊解雇了数百名 Alexa 员工。在人工智能方面，人们普遍认为该公司落后于 ChatGPT 母公司 OpenAI 等竞争对手。

十月

领英裁员

LinkedIn 表示，在今年的第二轮裁员中，该公司将裁掉来自工程、产品、人才和财务团队的约 668 名员工。 5 月，LinkedIn 表示将裁员 716 人，并关闭其在中国的求职应用程序。在两轮裁员之间，LinkedIn 将在 2023 年裁员近 1,400 人。

九月

Epic Games 裁员

Epic Games 解雇了 16%的员工，即约 830 名员工。首席执行官蒂姆·斯威尼(Tim Sweeney)在一封致员工的公开信中表示，公司花的钱比赚的钱“多得多”，“我们的结论是裁员是唯一的办法”。此前，该公司曾试图通过冻结招聘和削减营销支出来降低成本。

Roku裁员

Roku 2023 年第二轮裁员将导致另外 300 名员工离开公司，除了3 月份解雇的200 名员工以及 2022 年末解雇的另外 200 名员工之外。Roku 再次寻求降低成本，并在减少员工人数的同时，它正试图通过从其平台上删除节目和电影、整合办公空间并减少外部服务支出来做到这一点。

七月

谷歌裁员

谷歌在 7 月份引起了人们的关注，当时其合同合作伙伴埃森哲解雇了80 名帮助分包商，这些分包商在前一个月投票成立了 Alphabet 工人联盟 (CWA)。埃森哲将此举归因于削减成本。尽管该公司表示尊重分包商加入工会的权利，但前团队指责谷歌对劳工组织者进行报复。

CD Projekt Red 裁员

《赛博朋克 2077》的创作者也未能幸免于商业挑战。 CD Projekt Red 在 7 月份警告称，它将在未来几个月内裁员约 100 人，约占员工总数的 9%。员工最晚将在 2024 年第一季度被解雇。首席执行官 Adam Kiciński 坦白了原因：CDPR 因重组而“人满为患”，旨在更好地处理游戏开发商不断扩大的产品路线图，其中包括新的《赛博朋克》和《巫师》游戏。

六月

Spotify 裁员

Spotify 继 1 月份的裁员计划之后，于 6 月份宣布将在其播客部门裁员 200 人。此举是更有针对性的方法的一部分，旨在为创作者和节目提供优化的资源来培育播客。该公司还将其 Gimlet 和 Parcast 制作团队合并为新的 Spotify Studios 部门。

GrubHub 裁员

GrubHub 面临着来自经济和 Uber 等竞争对手的巨大压力，这导致其在 6 月份解雇了 15% 的员工，即大约 400 名员工。就在几周前，即将卸任的首席执行官亚当·德威特 (Adam DeWitt) 正式离开食品配送服务行业。新任首席执行官霍华德·米格达尔 (Howard Migdal) 声称，裁员将有助于公司保持“竞争力”。

拥抱集团裁员

游戏发行巨头 Embracer Group 于 6 月宣布了裁员计划，作为旨在削减成本的重大重组工作的一部分。该公司没有透露 17,000 名员工中有多少人会受到影响，但预计检修将持续到 3 月份。消息传出后不久，Embracer 透露，尽管有口头协议，但该公司还是失去了与一位未透露姓名的合作伙伴的 20 亿美元交易。

索诺斯裁员

Sonos 最近一直在努力扭亏为盈，并且正在削减成本以重回正轨。该公司 6 月份表示将裁员 7% ，即大约 130 个工作岗位。它还计划出售房地产并重新考虑项目支出。首席执行官帕特里克·斯宾塞表示，“持续的不利因素”包括销售萎缩。

普莱克斯裁员

Plex 可能是许多用户流媒体本地和在线媒体的首选应用程序，但这并没有帮助它的命运。该公司 6 月份解雇了大约 20% 的员工，即 37 人。削减影响到所有领域。据报道，Plex 感受到了广告市场放缓的打击，并渴望削减成本并扭亏为盈。

可能

Shopify裁员

Shopify 的电子商务平台在疫情最严重的时候发挥了重要作用，但这家加拿大公司现在正在缩减规模，因为疫情高峰已经结束。 5 月份，该公司解雇了20% 的员工，并将其物流业务出售给 Flexport。创始人 Tobi Lütke 表示，裁员是为了“全神贯注”Shopify 的核心使命所必需的，并承认既然“稳定的经济繁荣时期”已经结束，公司需要提高效率。

北极星裁员

Polestar 在 5 月份推迟了其首款电动 SUV（Polestar 3）的生产，这对其员工造成了影响。沃尔沃衍生品牌 5 月份表示，由于面临制造预期下降和经济不景气的情况，将裁员 10%以降低成本。 Polestar 表示，沃尔沃需要更多时间进行软件开发和测试，这也导致了 EX90 的推迟。

SoundCloud 裁员

SoundCloud 继去年大规模裁员之后，今年 5 月又进行了更多裁员。这家流媒体音频服务公司表示，为了在 2023 年实现盈利，它将裁员 8% 。Billboard消息人士称，该公司希望在今年第四季度实现盈利。

四月

Lyft 裁员

Lyft 于 2022 年 11 月解雇了 13% 的员工，但在 4 月份采取了进一步措施。这家拼车公司表示将裁员 1,072 名员工，约占其员工总数的 26%。就在几周前，亚马逊前高管大卫·瑞舍（David Risher）更换了首席执行官洛根·格林（Logan Green），后者表示该公司需要精简业务并重新关注司机和乘客。格林此前表示，Lyft 需要增加支出才能与 Uber 竞争。

Dropbox 裁员

云存储公司也无法免受当前金融环境的影响。 4 月份，Dropbox 表示将裁员 500 名员工，约占团队人数的 16%。联合创始人德鲁·休斯顿 (Drew Houston) 将此次裁员归咎于经济不景气、业务日趋成熟以及对人工智能日益增长的兴趣的“紧迫性”。休斯顿表示，虽然该公司实现盈利，但其增长正在放缓，一些投资“不再可持续”。

行进

Roku裁员

Roku 于 2022 年底裁员 200 人，但这一计划并未完成。这家流媒体平台创建者于 2023 年 3 月又解雇了 200 名员工。和以前一样，该公司辩称需要抑制不断增长的开支，并专注于那些影响最大的项目。 Roku 一直在艰难应对经济不景气和流媒体视频热潮结束的双重打击。

Lucid汽车公司裁员

如果您认为豪华电动汽车制造商特别容易受到经济动荡的影响，那么您猜对了。 Lucid Motors 在 3 月份表示，将裁员 18% ，即约 1,300 人。该品牌仍未达到生产目标，据报道，这些削减有助于应对“不断变化的业务需求和生产率的提高”。裁员也是全面的，包括高管和承包商。

Meta（Facebook）裁员

Meta 在 2022 年秋季裁员 11,000 人，但这还没有结束。 2023年3月，该公司宣布计划再裁员1万名，以进一步削减成本。第一次裁员影响了其招聘团队，但该公司在 4 月下旬缩减了技术团队，并在 5 月下旬缩减了业务部门。 Facebook 所有者希望通过减少管理层并要求一些领导者承担以前为普通员工保留的工作来简化其运营。 Meta 的员工人数可能需要一段时间才能再次增长——预计要到 2023 年底完成重组工作后才会解除招聘冻结。

二月

里维安裁员

Rivian 在 2022 年进行了裁员，但这不足以帮助这个羽翼未丰的电动汽车品牌实现盈利。 The company laid off another six percent of its employees in February, or about 840 workers. It's still fighting to achieve profitability, and the production shortfall from supply chain issues hasn't helped matters. CEO RJ Scaringe says the job cuts will help Rivian focus on the "highest impact" aspects of its business.

Zoom layoffs

Zoom was a staple of remote work culture at the pandemic's peak , so it's no surprise that the company is cutting back now that people are returning to offices. The video calling firm said in February it was laying off roughly 1,300 employees , or 15 percent of its personnel. As CEO Eric Yuan put it, the company didn't hire "sustainably" as it dealt with its sudden success. The layoffs are reportedly necessary to help survive a difficult economy. The management team is offering more than just apologies, too. Yuan is cutting his salary by 98 percent for the next fiscal year, while all other executives are losing 20 percent of their base salaries as well as their fiscal 2023 bonuses.

Yahoo layoffs

Engadget's parent company Yahoo isn't immune to layoffs. The internet brand said in February that it would lay off over 20 percent of its workforce throughout 2023, or more than 1,600 people. Most of those cuts, or about 1,000 positions, took place immediately. CEO Jim Lanzone didn't blame the layoffs on economic conditions, however. He instead pitched it as a restructuring of the advertising technology unit as it shed an unprofitable business in favor of a successful one. Effectively, Yahoo is bowing out of direct competition in with Google and Meta in the ad market.

Dell layoffs

The pandemic recovery and a grim economy have hit PC makers particularly hard, and Dell is feeling the pain more than most. It laid off five percent of its workforce in early February, or about 6,650 employees, after a brutal fourth quarter where computer shipments plunged an estimated 37 percent. Past cost-cutting efforts weren't enough, Dell said — the layoffs and a streamlined organization were reportedly needed to get back on track.

Deliveroo layoffs

Food delivery services flourished while COVID-19 kept people away from restaurants, and at least some are feeling the sting now that people are willing to dine out again. Deliveroo is laying off about 350 workers , or nine percent of its workforce. "Redeployments" will bring this closer to 300, according to founder Will Shu. The justification is familiar: Deliveroo hired rapidly to handle "unprecedented" pandemic-related growth, according to Shu, but reportedly has to cut costs as it deals with a troublesome economy.

DocuSign layoffs

DocuSign may be familiar to many people who've signed documents online, but that hasn't spared it from the impact of a harsh economic climate. The company said in mid-February that it was laying off 10 percent of its workforce . While it didn't disclose how many people that represented, the company had 7,461 employees at the start of 2022. Most of those losing their jobs work in DocuSign's worldwide field organization.

GitLab layoffs

You may not know GitLab, but its DevOps (development and operations) platform underpins work at tech brands like NVIDIA and T-Mobile — and shrinking business at its clients is affecting its bottom line. GitLab is laying off seven percent of employees , or roughly 114 people. Company chief Sid Sijbrandij said the problematic economy meant customers were taking a "more conservative approach" to software investment, and that his company's previous attempts to refocus spending weren't enough to counter these challenges.

GoDaddy layoffs

GoDaddy conducted layoffs early in the pandemic, when it cut over 800 workers for its retail-oriented Social platform. In February this year, however, it took broader action. The web service provider laid off eight percent of its workforce , or more than 500 people, across all divisions. Chief Aman Bhutani claimed other forms of cost-cutting hadn't been enough to help the company navigate an "uncertain" economy, and that this reflected efforts to further integrate acquisitions like Main Street Hub.

Twilio layoffs

Twilio eliminated over 800 jobs in September 2022, but it made deeper cuts as 2023 got started. The cloud communications brand laid off 17 percent of staff , or roughly 1,500 people, in mid-February. Like so many other tech firms, Twillio said that past cost reduction efforts weren't enough to endure an unforgiving environment. It also rationalized the layoffs as necessary for a streamlined organization.

January

Google (Alphabet) layoffs

Google's parent company Alphabet has been cutting costs for a while, including shutting down Stadia , but it took those efforts one step further in late January when it said it would lay off 12,000 employees . CEO Sundar Pichai wasn't shy about the reasoning: Alphabet had been hiring for a "different economic reality," and was restructuring to focus on the internet giant's most important businesses. The decision hit the company's Area 120 incubator particularly hard , with the majority of the unit's workers losing their jobs. Sub-brands like Intrinsic (robotics) and Verily (health) also shed significant portions of their workforce in the days before the mass layoffs. Waymo has conducted two rounds of layoffs that shed 209 people, or eight percent of its force.

Amazon layoffs

Amazon had already outlined layoff plans last fall, but expanded those cuts in early January when it said it would eliminate 18,000 jobs , most of them coming from retail and recruiting teams. It added another 9,000 people to the layoffs in March, and in April said over 100 gaming employees were leaving. To no one's surprise, CEO Andy Jassy blamed both an "uncertain economy" and rapid hiring in recent years. Amazon benefited tremendously from the pandemic as people shifted to online shopping, but its growth is slowing as people return to in-person stores.

Coinbase layoffs

Coinbase was one of the larger companies impacted by the crypto market's 2022 downturn, and that carried over into the new year. The cryptocurrency exchange laid off 950 people in mid-January, just months after it slashed 1,100 roles . This is one of the steepest proportionate cuts among larger tech brands — Coinbase offloaded about a fifth of its staff. Chief Brian Armstrong said his outfit needed the layoffs to shrink operating expenses and survive what he previously described as a "crypto winter," but that also meant canceling some projects that were less likely to succeed.

IBM layoffs

Layoffs sometimes stem more from corporate strategy shifts than financial hardship, and IBM provided a classic example of this in 2023. The computing pioneer axed 3,900 jobs in late January after offloading both its AI-driven Watson Health business and its infrastructure management division (now Kyndryl) in the fall. Simply put, those employees had nothing to work on as IBM pivoted toward cloud computing.

Microsoft layoffs

Microsoft started its second-largest wave of layoffs in company history when it signaled it would cut 10,000 jobs between mid-January and the end of March. Like many other tech heavyweights, it was trimming costs as customers scaled back their spending (particularly on Windows and devices) during the pandemic recovery. The reductions were especially painful for some divisions — they reportedly gutted the HoloLens and mixed reality teams , while 343 Industries is believed to be rebooting Halo development after losing dozens of workers. GitHub is cutting 10 percent of its team, or roughly 300 people.

PayPal layoffs

PayPal has been one of the healthier large tech companies, having beaten expectations in its third quarter last year. Still, it hasn't been immune to a tough economy. The online payment firm unveiled plans at the end of January to lay off 2,000 employees , or seven percent of its total worker base. CEO Dan Schulman claimed the downsizing would keep costs in check and help PayPal focus on "core strategic priorities."

Salesforce layoffs

Salesforce set the tone for 2023 when it warned it would lay off 8,000 employees , or about 10 percent of its workforce, just four days into the new year. While the cloud software brand thrived during the pandemic with rapidly growing revenue, it admitted that it hired too aggressively during the boom and couldn't maintain that staffing level while the economy was in decline.

SAP layoffs

Business software powerhouse SAP saw a steep 68 percent drop in profit at the end of 2022, and it started 2023 by laying off 2,800 staff to keep its business healthy. Unlike some big names in tech, though, SAP didn't blame excessive pandemic-era hiring for the cutback. Instead, it characterized the initiative as a "targeted restructuring" for a company that still expected accelerating growth in 2023.

Spotify layoffs

Spotify spent aggressively in recent years as it expanded its podcast empire , but it quickly put a stop to that practice as 2023 began. The streaming music service said in late January that it would lay off 6 percent of its workforce (9,800 people worked at Spotify as of the third quarter) alongside a restructuring effort that included the departure of content chief Dawn Ostroff. While there were more Premium subscribers than ever in 2022, the company also suffered steep losses — CEO Daniel Ek said he was "too ambitious" investing before the revenue existed to support it.

Wayfair layoffs

Amazon isn't the only major online retailer scaling back in 2023. Wayfair said in late January that it would lay off 1,750 team members , or 10 percent of its global headcount. About 1,200 of those were corporate staff cut in a bid to "eliminate management layers" and otherwise help the company become leaner and nimbler. Wayfair had been cutting costs since August 2022 (including 870 positions), but saw the layoffs as helping it reach break-even earnings sooner than expected.

Amazon is sacking employees in its Alexa division even as it prepares to upgrade Alexa to be as smart as modern AI-powered chatbots like ChatGPT. The move will impact several hundred employees in the US, Canada, and India, according to an internal email sent on Friday.

“As we continue to invent, we're shifting some of our efforts to better align with our business priorities, and what we know matters most to customers — which includes maximizing our resources and efforts focused on generative AI,” wrote Daniel Bausch, Amazon's vice president of Alexa and Fire TV in the email, first obtained by GeekWire . “These shifts are leading us to discontinue some initiatives, which is resulting in several hundred roles being eliminated.”

An Amazon spokesperson confirmed to Engadget that the company was, indeed, laying off “several hundred” people in the division and said that Amazon was trying to find roles for those impacted wherever possible. “While this was a hard decision to make, we remain very optimistic about the future of Alexa,” the spokesperson said in a statement. “As we move forward, Alexa remains an incredibly important part of our business, and we will continue to invest and innovate to deliver on our vision.” The spokesperson did not say which initiatives were being discontinued.

Amazon released Alexa in 2014. But nearly ten years later, most people don't use the digital assistant for anything beyond playing music, asking for the weather, or setting timers. OpenAI's ChatGPT, which was powered by generative AI, was widely perceived to be smarter than Alexa and Siri, which sometimes struggle with basic requests. A few months ago, OpenAI added voice capabilities to ChatGPT, letting people have conversations with it in natural language.

In September, Amazon announced that it would upgrade Alexa with capabilities that would bring it closer in line with ChatGPT. Alexa will soon be powered by a large language model, the same foundational technology that is the basis of modern chatbots like ChatGPT. “Our latest model has been specifically optimized for voice,” David Limp, Amazon's SVP of Devices & Services, told the audience at the company's event that month, “and the things we know our customers love — like having access to real-time information, efficiently controlling their smart home, and getting the most out of their home entertainment.” Earlier this year, Limp announced he would leave Amazon after more than 13 years later this year and is now the CEO of Jeff Bezos' space company Blue Origin.

The new upgrades to Alexa will mean that you won't have to say “Alexa” each time you want something done. You'll also be able to give complex requests, like asking the assistant to prepare the house for bedtime every weeknight at 9 PM, dim the lights, lock the doors, and set the temperature all at one go. Alexa will also be able to hold longer conversations and maintain the context of the discussion.

Amazon has so far laid off more than 27,000 employees across the company after it began mass-scale cutbacks a year ago for the first time in its history. Last week, the company cut 180 jobs from its gaming division, including the entire staff of Crown, a company-backed Twitch channel. Earlier this month, Amazon also laid off an unspecified number of employees in its music streaming unit and has previously cut more than 100 employees from its gaming divisions.
